DataElement.preferredDefinition: information related to a specimen being submitted._A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._The act of referring for judgment or consideration by others; the act of handing over something._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a specimen being submitted.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: Submitted; referred for judgment or consideration.

Concepts.definition: The act of referring for judgment or consideration by others; the act of handing over something.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: released; merged information from duplicate DEC #2012957

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._The act of referring for judgment or consideration by others; the act of handing over something._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Formaldehyde Solution Fixed Specimen Paraffin Malignant Neoplasm Slide Device Component

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Formaldehyde Solution Fixed Specimen Paraffin Malignant Neoplasm Slide Device Component
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A saturated solution of formaldehyde, water, and typically another agent, most commonly methanol. In its typical form, formalin is 37% formaldehyde by weight (40% by volume), 6-13% methanol, and the rest water.: Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: A saturated solution of formaldehyde, water, and typically another agent, most commonly methanol. In its typical form, formalin is 37% formaldehyde by weight (40% by volume), 6-13% methanol, and the rest water.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.

A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stained Appearance Cytology Slide Device Component

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stained Appearance Cytology Slide Device Component
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: Marked or discolored by foreign material.
The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Unstained Specimen Cytology Slide Device Component

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Unstained Specimen Cytology Slide Device Component
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study but without preparation methods which use dyes, reagents or other materials to produce coloration in tissues or microorganisms for microscopic examination.: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study but without preparation methods which use dyes, reagents or other materials to produce coloration in tissues or microorganisms for microscopic examination.
The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A saturated solution of formaldehyde, water, and typically another agent, most commonly methanol. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.: A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.

Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

Concepts.definition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fluid containing water and waste products. Urine is made by the kidneys, stored in the bladder, and leaves the body through the urethra.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

Concepts.definition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tissue that is not frozen or embedded in preservatives

Concepts.definition: Tissue that is not frozen or embedded in preservatives

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The DNA that is part of the normal chromosomal complement of an organism.

Concepts.definition: The DNA that is part of the normal chromosomal complement of an organism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the amount of the human anti-mouse antibody in a sample.: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of the human anti-mouse antibody in a sample.
The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

The act of referring for judgment or consideration by others; the act of handing over something.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
